body: FOR a little more than a decade, the city has auctioned off rights to sell Christmas trees at locations managed by the Parks and Recreation Department. The program generated $144,959 in fees last year, 58 percent more than the year before. This year, the number of concession sites grew to 24 from 21. The parks commissioner, Adrian Benepe, said he
title: ON THE RECORDS | HOLIDAY VENDORS; Buy a Tree in a Park

author: Michael Emmer is a retired high school teacher who lives in Marine Park, Brooklyn. Post your comment on his rant at nytimes.com/cityroom.
body: As we move through fall toward winter, I can sense the local news channels gearing up their daily love-hate relationship with the weather. It was not always so. When I was growing up in the 1950s and '60s, television and radio weather reporters were usually called forecasters, not meteorologists. Their reports were short. Precipitation,
title: COMPLAINT BOX WEATHER FORECASTS; You Call That a Storm?

body: MANY blocks in Midwood, with its rows of orderly detached homes and private driveways, give the feeling of a carefully planned suburb -- a serene surprise after turning off a thoroughfare like Coney Island Avenue or Ocean Parkway. But closer inspection reveals that the landscape has, in fact, been altered: on virtually every block, at least one or
title: LIVING IN | MIDWOOD, BROOKLYN; Where Prosperity Breeds Proximity

body: Suzanne Tecza had spent a year redesigning the library at Middle School 126 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, including colorful new furniture and elaborate murals of leafy trees. So when her principal decided this year to give the space to the charter high schools that share the building, Ms. Tecza was furious. ''It's not fair to our students,'' she said
title: City's Schools Share Space, And Bitterness, With Charters

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites BARTOW-PELL MANSION MUSEUM Friday at 5:30 p.m., a performance by Stephen Dydo, a classical guitarist. Saturday, 10 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., a bicycle tour of historical and architectural sites in the East Bronx; free. Museum hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m.; grounds open daily, 8:30 a.m. to dusk. 895
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE Friday, 5 to 9 p.m., a ceremony in remembrance of Sept. 11 and the firefighters who died; also sponsored by the Staten Island Firefighters. Saturday, noon to 4 p.m., a celebration of the 400th anniversary of Henry Hudson's voyage, with crafts workshops and displays; donation, $5; materials fee, $5.
title: Spare Times

body: IT would be wrong to begin with anything but the beach. This tiny neighborhood, a mere four by eight blocks of the Rockaway peninsula in southern Queens, is bounded to the north by Jamaica Bay and to the south by the Atlantic Ocean. That proximity to the ocean defines Neponsit, from its blocks of waterfront mansions to the chummy neighborhood
title: LIVING IN | NEPONSIT, QUEENS; A Beach Shared by a Tight-Knit Clan

body: BROLLY--Michael T. Peacefully entered into his eternal rest in heaven on August 10, 2009. Loving and devoted husband of the late Patricia (nee Hamilton). Dear son of the late James and Margaret (nee Trainor). Extraordinary and supportive father of Margaret Dugan and her husband Patrick, Patricia Brolly-Thorsen and her husband Thomas and Mary
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BROLLY, MICHAEL T

body: GALLAGHER--John P.,on August 3, 2009. Beloved husband of Katherine (nee Tunny). Loving father of John and his wife, Mary, David and his wife, Kerry, Shelagh O'Brien and her husband, Cletus, Brendan and his wife, Debbie and Katie Stripeikis and her husband, Lenny. Dear brother of Mary Gallagher. Cherished grandfather of 15. Funeral Thursday, 9am
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GALLAGHER, JOHN P.

body: GALLAGHER--John P.,on August 3, 2009. Beloved husband of Katherine (nee Tunny). Loving father of John and his wife, Mary, David and his wife, Kerry, Shelagh O'Brien and her husband, Cletus, Brendan and his wife, Debbie and Katie Stripeikis and her husband, Lenny. Dear brother of Mary Gallagher. Cherished grandfather of 15. Funeral Thursday, 9am
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GALLAGHER, JOHN P.

body: A police officer whose left leg had to be amputated after he was struck by a car while on duty in Brooklyn two weeks ago left the hospital on Monday afternoon, saying more with a gesture than he did with words. Instead of being pushed out of Kings County Hospital Center in a wheelchair, Officer Eric Grimes made his way to a waiting van on crutches,
title: Colleagues Cheer Spirit Of Officer After Injury

body: Despite his nickname, Short Al stood tall in the pantheon of overnight callers to talk shows on the New York sports radio station WFAN-AM. Such callers, sometimes called FANdroids, are known by name, neighborhood and loyalties. Bruce from Bayside likes the Cleveland Indians, while Bruce from Flushing is a Yankees man. There is Marc in the Bronx
title: Why Short Al, Talkative Fan, Calls No More

body: AROUND TOWN New York City DECLARATION OF INDEPENDENCE, handwritten by Thomas Jefferson, on view through Aug. 1 at the New York Public Library, Sue and Edgar Wachenheim III Gallery, Stephen A. Schwarzman Building, Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Also on view: early printings of the document and a letter to George Washington from Benjamin Franklin.
title: Around Town

body: Matt Egan, 24, has been working for the Fox Business Network since September 2007, mostly covering the stock market. He was born in Colombia, raised in Edison, N.J. A graduate of the College of New Jersey, he won the National Hispanic Recognition Program scholarship, awarded to the top 2 percent of all Hispanic high school students. Birthplace:
title: ENTRY LEVEL; Crash Course In Working A Beat On Wall St.

body: FOR NINO CONIGLIO, pizza is performance. He tosses circles of dough like a Harlem Globetrotter juggles basketballs. He can spin two at once, juggle them, sling them around his back and behind his head and flip them between his legs while leaping. He can roll them sideways across his arm span, or lie on his back and keep them orbiting above and
title: STREET TAKES | PIZZA THROWER; When It Comes to Tossing a Pie, He Cooks

body: During the regular announcements on Wednesday morning at Ascension School, a Roman Catholic school on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a boy named Kevin threw up and was sent home. It would ordinarily not have attracted a lot of attention. Children get sick at school every day. But on this day it was the topic of intense after-school talk, and
title: School Days Are Disrupted, by Facts and Fears of Flu

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: As Cheap as Water Q.Eight ounces of Poland Spring (plus a nice plastic bottle) costs about a dollar. How much does the same amount straight from the tap cost? I mean, how much does it really cost? A. One two-thousandth as much, according to the city's Department of Environmental Protection. Both the mayor and the City Council have voiced their
title: F. Y. I.

body: There were days when Patricia Campbell could not get out of bed. Over the course of two years, she had fallen from her $70,000-per-year dream job to the doldrums of on-again-off-again work. She was subsisting on a diet of cereal, and her cats -- Priscilla, Baby Boy and Pandora -- seemed to be the only ones who cared about her plight. As Ms.
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Coping With the Loss of Steady Work

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: They didn't give Frank Perri the nickname Buzz back in high school because he ran fast, or because he liked to mess around with slot cars, the miniature electric vehicles that zoom around a track. They called him Buzz because he was a star high jumper, and that was the sound the appreciative crowd made when he soared over a pole six feet off the
title: BIG CITY; The Buzz in Brooklyn Is Still All About Speed

body: For the last several years, Lester Futernick has lived alone inside his childhood apartment in Brooklyn with little more to keep him company than faded old pictures of his parents, the giant portrait of himself at his bar mitzvah, some fantasy baseball guides and an overweight cat named Matzoh. He is divorced, an only child. His parents passed away
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; When a Tolerable Solitude Turns Intolerable, Help Arrives
